title: How to profit from my original songs - Quora

response.answer_text: If I knew the answer to that I’d be a millionaire by now. But that doesn’t mean that it can’t happen with a lot of work and investment and luck. Pick your absolute best most commercially viable song. Assuming you’re more of a writer than a singer find a wonderfully talented singer or band that is A) looking for new material and B) has a style that fits with your song. By “fit” I mean, if you’ve found a rapper but your song leans more toward country, that’s not a fit. Enter an agreement with your new found talent whereby you will supply the song and pay for the recording and the video and they will provide the talent. Finding the talent will be the hard part. Getting them to agree to your deal will be the easy part. There are pros and cons as to whether to go with a band or a solo artist. The pros of working with a band are that they are a complete unit, you won’t have to hire any other musicians. The cons are that typically in a band each member has his/her own interpretation of the music and/or his/her own importance to the band as a whole. There can be a lot of very sensitive egos involved. Each member will have their own input and suggestions and may get upset if their suggestions aren’t followed. However, if you find that you have the patience and temperament to get through this phase, get a finished product, and with the band still together and all working together then you might find that you could be a successful manager, taking 10–15% of the band’s earnings. The cons of working with a solo artist are that you have to find and organize other musicians for the recording. However, the pros being that you have only one personality, one ego to contend with. So it’s a trade off. Whether you’re dealing with a band or a solo artist you will have to find some place and time to rehearse. The band might already have a rehearsal space if you’re lucky. Having all the singers and musicians together in one space you’ll need to come up with an arrangement. If you are an experienced musician this might come easy to you. But it’s not a bad idea to ask for input from each instrumentalist to some extent. They will always appreciate that. However, even if you have very specific ideas about an arrangement, still make sure to leave room for individual creativity. By that I mean, for example, you know where in the song you want a guitar solo. You won’t have to tell him what notes to play, he can figure that from the chord progression of the song. But you can make suggestions as to style (is it more like Eddie Van Halen or more like Chuck Berry) and volume. Other than that give them as much freedom as you feel comfortable with. Once you have worked out an arrangement and have rehearsed it to near perfection then you’re ready to go into a studio. Two things to note here. By now you should know what kind of drummer you’re dealing with. If he/she tight as a metronome or does he tend more toward following the bass player? If he’s tight then don’t worry about it. But if he’s “iffy” then have him practice on his own with a metronome or click track. A click track is a steady beat clicking along with the recording. If you don’t practice playing to one you’ll never be able to stay with it. It’s that simple. Find the tempo that works best for the song and make sure he practices his butt off to that click track. That accomplished, find a studio. This is not as difficult as it was when i was doing this back in the 80s. Everybody and their dog has a laptop with protools on is and a couple of mics. These guys are not necessarily the ones you want but you never know, you might be surprised. Go online and google recording studios in your area. You can still find them on craigslist. You will find quite a variety of levels and prices. Depending on where you live you can find studios from $15 up to $150 an hour or more. I’m going to assume that you’re not ready to spend $150 and hour. But you can get quality for about $30 and hour if you book a block of ten hours or more. If you live in the Los Angeles area there’s nothing better I’ve found at any price than Big Scary Tree Studios in Sunland. Call around, ask for pricing and ask for to hear samples. If they don’t have sample you might want to move on to the next one. It means they either haven’t been in business long or they have never recorded anything they’re proud enough to show. Some will actually have samples that aren’t impressive so, you’re sort of on your own to find the best studio for your budget. Talk to the engineer and make sure he has experience recording your kind of music. Sometimes you can discern this based on the ad they post online. For example if he’s talking about recording “beats” he probably doesn’t have a lot of experience recording disco, and vice versa. Depending on how tight your band is at this point you might need about 10 hours of studio time for recording basic tracks. Basic tracks would be most of the instruments, not including the vocal and any overdubs. Once you have the basic tracks finished then you begin work on the lead vocal. If your singer is good you can get this done in a couple hours at most, including backing vocals if necessary. Once this is done you’ll need about 4 or 5 hours for mixing. Maybe less if it’s a simple arrangement. Once you have a mix that you love you’ll need to get it mastered. Your recording engineer might know someone who can do this. If he’s honest he’ll admit that it’s not his forte. Mastering is a whole different animal than recording and mixing. It’s really an art form. Once you have your recording mastered then your ready to shoot a video. Go back to google or craigslist and find a music video producer/director. You’ll find these the same way you found your studio. Again, ask to see samples. If you have ideas about how you want the video to go then look for a producer who is willing to incorporate your ideas. But some of these guys think they’re the next Spielberg so you might have to deal with his ego. I don’t know what to tell you about that. make sure that his shooting and editing are all included in his price. And make sure that he puts a credit at the end, listing the song, artist and composer. Now you have the finished video. Create a channel of youtube. You’ll have to do some research into how monetisation works because i’m not that familiar with it. Upload the video and send a link to everyone who worked on it in anyway shape or form. If it goes viral then you’re on your way. Keep close ties to everyone you worked with so you can start the whole process over again as soon as possible. As you can see it’s going to take an investment of a lot of time, effort and money. But nothing worthwhile is easy. Good luck
